docs.lead_paragraph: The woman who was severely beaten in Central Park two weeks ago has regained consciousness and begun to communicate, a neurosurgeon at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center said, calling the change an "absolutely crucial step" toward recovery. On Wednesday, the 32-year-old piano teacher demonstrated awareness for the first time since the attack by responding to simple questions with a nod or shake of the head and by mouthing her name, the surgeon, Dr. Jamshid Ghajar, said. And yesterday, able to move her arms and legs, she sat up in a chair with help -- also a first.

headline.main: Central Park Victim Awakens in 'Crucial Step' to Recovery

docs.snippet: The woman who was severely beaten in Central Park two weeks ago has regained  consciousness and begun to communicate, a neurosurgeon at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center said, calling the change an "absolutely crucial  step" toward recovery.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nine members of a union that used to represent workers at the corruption-plagued Jacob K. Javits Convention Center were charged yesterday with illegally obtaining union health benefits, unemployment compensation and Social Security benefits, as well as with loan sharking. The charges against members of the Exhibition Employees Union Local 829, including the local president and vice president, were the first connected to the Javits Center since Gov. George E. Pataki announced a major reorganization at the center last summer. The union no longer represents workers there, and the crimes the men are accused of occurred before the reorganization.

headline.main: 9 in Former Javits Center Union Held in Fraud

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re your June 15 Business Day item on Leonard Abramson, the U.S. Healthcare chairman, who will receive about $1 billion as a result of U.S. Healthcare's merger with Aetna Life and Casualty Company:

headline.main: Maximum Wage? Tell It to Movers and Shakers;Health Care Capitalism

docs.lead_paragraph: White House officials met again today with Republican Congressional aides to seek a compromise on the Republican proposal for medical savings accounts but made little progress on the issue, the last obstacle to final passage of a bill that would make health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans. Indeed, negotiators said they were further apart now than several days ago, when an agreement seemed to be taking shape. But both sides vowed to continue work on the bill, which is intended to guarantee continued health insurance coverage for workers who change jobs.

headline.main: Talks on the Health Care Bill Appear to Move Backward

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislative leaders have reached agreement on a bill that would require health insurance companies to pay for unlimited chiropractic services, a move that would confer new legitimacy upon a profession that remains embroiled in a debate over its effectiveness. Responding to a tenacious lobbying campaign by chiropractors and their patients, the State Assembly is expected to pass the legislation by a wide margin within the next week. The State Senate approved it, by a vote of 56 to 0, in February.

headline.main: Bill Requires Insurers to Pay Chiropractors

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST health maintenance companies had a disappointing first quarter, and the gloom is not expected to lift when they report their financial results again next month. While some analysts expect the health maintenance organizations to improve later in the year, as they did last year after a weak first half, others say they are in a down cycle that may continue into 1997.

headline.main: Market Place;H.M.O.'s are having trouble maintaining financial health.

docs.lead_paragraph: Valujet Forced to Halt Its Operations Indefinitely The Federal Aviation Administration shut down Valujet indefinitely, saying that an evaluation begun after the airline's May 11 Everglades crash had turned up "serious deficiencies" in its operations. David R. Hinson, the agency's Administrator, said those included "multiple shortcomings" in its supervision of maintenance contractors.
